title: Auditory Processing Disorder Therapy for Mitochondrial Myopathy
chief_complaint: The patient states, "No one knows how to treat me." Her sister reports she has lost the ability to read and write, has difficulty understanding speech in noise, and gets frustrated easily.

problem_summary.onset: Symptoms began at age 20 with reading and speech-in-noise difficulties; diagnosed with Mitochondrial Myopathy (MM) at age 40.
problem_summary.course: Progressive and degenerative. Condition worsened until she lost the ability to read and developed significant speech and memory problems.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Muscle weakness, fatigue, 'machine gun' style speech (staccato/unrelated sounds), word-finding difficulties, short-term memory loss, poor handwriting.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Unable to write (sister completed history), graduated college/business prior to onset but now has severe communication and literacy deficits.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Seeking treatment for APD symptoms after referral from MM specialist and SLP.

history.present_illness: Patient has Mitochondrial Myopathy. At age 20, noticed issues with reading and background noise. Now presents with severe speech processing, memory, and literacy deficits.
history.medical_psych_history: Diagnosed with Mitochondrial Myopathy (degenerative neurological disorder). Anxiety and emotional issues noted.
history.prior_management: Referred by MM specialist and SLP.
history.patient_goals: To find a treatment path as she feels no one knows how to help her.

numeric_results.Right Thresholds: All tested frequencies (250-8000 Hz) within 10-25 dB HL range
numeric_results.Left Thresholds: All tested frequencies (250-8000 Hz) within 15-25 dB HL range

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Normal speech recognition thresholds and excellent word recognition in quiet.

tests.name: Buffalo Model Questionnaire (BMQ)
tests.key_findings: Results are severe for an adult. Indicates deficits in Decoding (DEC), Tolerance-Fading Memory (TFM), and Integration (INT).

tests.name: Staggered Spondaic Word (SSW)
tests.key_findings: Extremely poor performance, indicating severe central auditory dysfunction.

tests.name: Phonemic Synthesis (PS)
tests.key_findings: Performance is significantly below normal limits.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with normal peripheral hearing sensitivity and excellent word recognition in quiet. However, central auditory processing evaluation reveals severe deficits. She scored 18 SDs below normal on the SSW and 16 SDs below normal on Phonemic Synthesis, consistent with Decoding (DEC) and Tolerance-Fading Memory (TFM) subtypes of APD. Questionnaire results corroborate these findings, showing significant difficulty with processing speed, noise, and memory.
counseling_points: Your peripheral hearing (the ears themselves) is normal, but the way your brain processes sound is significantly affected by the mitochondrial myopathy.
The 'power cells' (mitochondria) in your brain are struggling to provide enough energy for complex listening tasks, which explains your fatigue and difficulty with reading and speech.
We have identified specific patterns (Decoding and Memory issues) that we can target with therapy.
Therapy will start with basic skills like recognizing speech sounds and will gradually move to more complex tasks as you improve.
